args.description: Explains why this element was deprecated, usually also including a suggestion for how to access supported similar data. Formatted in [Markdown](https://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/).
args.name: reason

directives.description: The @deprecated built-in directive is used within the type system definition language to indicate deprecated portions of a GraphQL service's schema, such as deprecated fields on a type, arguments on a field, input fields on an input type, or values of an enum type.
directives.name: deprecated

args.description: Explains why this element is impure, i.e. whether it performs side effects or yield a different result with the same arguments.
args.name: reason

directives.description: Indicates that a field may resolve to different values when called repeatedly with the same inputs, or that the field has side effects. Impure fields are never cached.
directives.name: impure

directives.description: Indicates that a field's selection can be removed from any query without changing the result. Meta fields are dropped from cache keys.
directives.name: meta

types.description: The `Boolean` scalar type represents `true` or `false`.
types.name: Boolean

types.description: Key value object that represents a build argument.
types.name: BuildArg

types.description: Sharing mode of the cache volume.

enumValues.description: Shares the cache volume amongst many build pipelines
enumValues.name: SHARED

enumValues.description: Keeps a cache volume for a single build pipeline
enumValues.name: PRIVATE

enumValues.description: Shares the cache volume amongst many build pipelines, but will serialize the writes
enumValues.name: LOCKED

types.name: CacheSharingMode

types.description: A directory whose contents persist across runs.

fields.description: A unique identifier for this CacheVolume.
fields.name: id

types.name: CacheVolume

types.description: The `CacheVolumeID` scalar type represents an identifier for an object of type CacheVolume.
types.name: CacheVolumeID

types.description: An OCI-compatible container, also known as a Docker container.

fields.description:
Turn the container into a Service.

Be sure to set any exposed ports before this conversion.
fields.name: asService

args.description:
Identifiers for other platform specific containers.

Used for multi-platform images.
args.name: platformVariants

args.description:
Force each layer of the image to use the specified compression algorithm.

If this is unset, then if a layer already has a compressed blob in the engine's cache, that will be used (this can result in a mix of compression algorithms for different layers). If this is unset and a layer has no compressed blob in the engine's cache, then it will be compressed using Gzip.
args.name: forcedCompression

args.description:
Use the specified media types for the image's layers.

Defaults to OCI, which is largely compatible with most recent container runtimes, but Docker may be needed for older runtimes without OCI support.
args.name: mediaTypes

fields.description: Returns a File representing the container serialized to a tarball.
fields.name: asTarball

args.description: Directory context used by the Dockerfile.
args.name: context

args.description: Path to the Dockerfile to use.
args.name: dockerfile

args.description: Target build stage to build.
args.name: target

args.description: Additional build arguments.
args.name: buildArgs

args.description:
Secrets to pass to the build.

They will be mounted at /run/secrets/[secret-name] in the build container

They can be accessed in the Dockerfile using the "secret" mount type and mount path /run/secrets/[secret-name], e.g. RUN --mount=type=secret,id=my-secret curl http://example.com?token=$(cat /run/secrets/my-secret)
args.name: secrets

fields.description: Initializes this container from a Dockerfile build.
fields.name: build

fields.description: Retrieves default arguments for future commands.
fields.name: defaultArgs

args.description: The path of the directory to retrieve (e.g., "./src").
args.name: path

fields.description:
Retrieves a directory at the given path.

Mounts are included.
fields.name: directory

fields.description: Retrieves entrypoint to be prepended to the arguments of all commands.
fields.name: entrypoint

args.description: The name of the environment variable to retrieve (e.g., "PATH").
args.name: name

fields.description: Retrieves the value of the specified environment variable.
fields.name: envVariable

fields.description: Retrieves the list of environment variables passed to commands.
fields.name: envVariables

fields.description:
EXPERIMENTAL API! Subject to change/removal at any time.

Configures all available GPUs on the host to be accessible to this container.

This currently works for Nvidia devices only.
fields.name: experimentalWithAllGPUs

args.description: List of devices to be accessible to this container.
args.name: devices

fields.description:
EXPERIMENTAL API! Subject to change/removal at any time.

Configures the provided list of devices to be accesible to this container.

This currently works for Nvidia devices only.
fields.name: experimentalWithGPU

args.description:
Host's destination path (e.g., "./tarball").

Path can be relative to the engine's workdir or absolute.
args.name: path

args.description:
Identifiers for other platform specific containers.

Used for multi-platform image.
args.name: platformVariants

args.description:
Force each layer of the exported image to use the specified compression algorithm.

If this is unset, then if a layer already has a compressed blob in the engine's cache, that will be used (this can result in a mix of compression algorithms for different layers). If this is unset and a layer has no compressed blob in the engine's cache, then it will be compressed using Gzip.
args.name: forcedCompression

args.description:
Use the specified media types for the exported image's layers.

Defaults to OCI, which is largely compatible with most recent container runtimes, but Docker may be needed for older runtimes without OCI support.
args.name: mediaTypes

fields.description:
Writes the container as an OCI tarball to the destination file path on the host.

Return true on success.

It can also export platform variants.
fields.name: export

fields.description:
Retrieves the list of exposed ports.

This includes ports already exposed by the image, even if not explicitly added with dagger.
fields.name: exposedPorts

args.description: The path of the file to retrieve (e.g., "./README.md").
args.name: path

fields.description:
Retrieves a file at the given path.

Mounts are included.
fields.name: file

args.description:
Image's address from its registry.

Formatted as [host]/[user]/[repo]:[tag] (e.g., "docker.io/dagger/dagger:main").
args.name: address

fields.description: Initializes this container from a pulled base image.
fields.name: from

fields.name: id

fields.name: imageRef

args.name: name

args.description:
Registry's address to publish the image to.

Formatted as [host]/[user]/[repo]:[tag] (e.g. "docker.io/dagger/dagger:main").
args.name: address

args.description:
Identifiers for other platform specific containers.

Used for multi-platform image.
args.name: platformVariants

args.description:
Force each layer of the published image to use the specified compression algorithm.

If this is unset, then if a layer already has a compressed blob in the engine's cache, that will be used (this can result in a mix of compression algorithms for different layers). If this is unset and a layer has no compressed blob in the engine's cache, then it will be compressed using Gzip.
args.name: forcedCompression

args.description:
Use the specified media types for the published image's layers.

Defaults to OCI, which is largely compatible with most recent registries, but Docker may be needed for older registries without OCI support.
args.name: mediaTypes

fields.description:
Publishes this container as a new image to the specified address.

Publish returns a fully qualified ref.

It can also publish platform variants.
fields.name: publish

fields.description: Retrieves this container's root filesystem. Mounts are not included.
fields.name: rootfs

args.description: If set, override the container's default shell and invoke these arguments instead.
args.name: args

fields.description: Return an interactive terminal for this container using its configured shell if not overridden by args (or sh as a fallback default).
fields.name: shell

fields.description:
The error stream of the last executed command.

Will execute default command if none is set, or error if there's no default.
fields.name: stderr

fields.description:
The output stream of the last executed command.

Will execute default command if none is set, or error if there's no default.
fields.name: stdout

fields.description:
Forces evaluation of the pipeline in the engine.

It doesn't run the default command if no exec has been set.
fields.name: sync

fields.description: Retrieves the user to be set for all commands.
fields.name: user

args.description: Arguments to prepend to future executions (e.g., ["-v", "--no-cache"]).
args.name: args

fields.description: Configures default arguments for future commands.
fields.name: withDefaultArgs

args.description: The args of the command to set the default shell to.
args.name: args

fields.description: Set the default command to invoke for the "shell" API.
fields.name: withDefaultShell

args.description: Location of the written directory (e.g., "/tmp/directory").
args.name: path

args.description: Identifier of the directory to write
args.name: directory

args.description: Patterns to exclude in the written directory (e.g. ["node_modules/**", ".gitignore", ".git/"]).
args.name: exclude

args.description: Patterns to include in the written directory (e.g. ["*.go", "go.mod", "go.sum"]).
args.name: include

args.description:
A user:group to set for the directory and its contents.

The user and group can either be an ID (1000:1000) or a name (foo:bar).

If the group is omitted, it defaults to the same as the user.
args.name: owner

fields.description: Retrieves this container plus a directory written at the given path.
fields.name: withDirectory

args.description: Entrypoint to use for future executions (e.g., ["go", "run"]).
args.name: args

args.description: Don't remove the default arguments when setting the entrypoint.
args.name: keepDefaultArgs

fields.description: Retrieves this container but with a different command entrypoint.
fields.name: withEntrypoint

args.description: The name of the environment variable (e.g., "HOST").
args.name: name

args.description: The value of the environment variable. (e.g., "localhost").
args.name: value

args.description: Replace `${VAR}` or `$VAR` in the value according to the current environment variables defined in the container (e.g., "/opt/bin:$PATH").
args.name: expand

fields.description: Retrieves this container plus the given environment variable.
fields.name: withEnvVariable

args.description:
Command to run instead of the container's default command (e.g., ["run", "main.go"]).

If empty, the container's default command is used.
args.name: args

args.description: If the container has an entrypoint, ignore it for args rather than using it to wrap them.
args.name: skipEntrypoint

args.description: Content to write to the command's standard input before closing (e.g., "Hello world").
args.name: stdin

args.description: Redirect the command's standard output to a file in the container (e.g., "/tmp/stdout").
args.name: redirectStdout

args.description: Redirect the command's standard error to a file in the container (e.g., "/tmp/stderr").
args.name: redirectStderr

args.description:
Provides dagger access to the executed command.

Do not use this option unless you trust the command being executed; the command being executed WILL BE GRANTED FULL ACCESS TO YOUR HOST FILESYSTEM.
args.name: experimentalPrivilegedNesting

args.description: Execute the command with all root capabilities. This is similar to running a command with "sudo" or executing "docker run" with the "--privileged" flag. Containerization does not provide any security guarantees when using this option. It should only be used when absolutely necessary and only with trusted commands.
args.name: insecureRootCapabilities

fields.description: Retrieves this container after executing the specified command inside it.
fields.name: withExec

args.description: Port number to expose
args.name: port

args.description: Transport layer network protocol
args.name: protocol

args.description: Optional port description
args.name: description

args.description: Skip the health check when run as a service.
args.name: experimentalSkipHealthcheck

fields.description:
Expose a network port.

Exposed ports serve two purposes:

- For health checks and introspection, when running services

- For setting the EXPOSE OCI field when publishing the container
fields.name: withExposedPort

A user:group to set for the mounted cache directory.

Note that this changes the ownership of the specified mount along with the initial filesystem provided by source (if any). It does not have any effect if/when the cache has already been created.

The user and group can either be an ID (1000:1000) or a name (foo:bar).

If the group is omitted, it defaults to the same as the user.

fields.description:
Establish a runtime dependency on a service.

The service will be started automatically when needed and detached when it is no longer needed, executing the default command if none is set.

The service will be reachable from the container via the provided hostname alias.

The service dependency will also convey to any files or directories produced by the container.
fields.name: withServiceBinding

args.description:
An optional subpath of the directory which contains the module's source code.

This is needed when the module code is in a subdirectory but requires parent directories to be loaded in order to execute. For example, the module source code may need a go.mod, project.toml, package.json, etc. file from a parent directory.

If not set, the module source code is loaded from the root of the directory.

args.description:
Ports to expose via the service, forwarding through the host network.

If a port's frontend is unspecified or 0, it defaults to the same as the backend port.

An empty set of ports is not valid; an error will be returned.
args.name: ports

fields.description: Creates a service that forwards traffic to a specified address via the host.
fields.name: service

args.description: The user defined name for this secret.
args.name: name

args.description: Location of the file to set as a secret.
args.name: path

fields.description:
Sets a secret given a user-defined name and the file path on the host, and returns the secret.

The file is limited to a size of 512000 bytes.
fields.name: setSecretFile

args.description: Service to send traffic from the tunnel.
args.name: service

args.description:
Configure explicit port forwarding rules for the tunnel.

If a port's frontend is unspecified or 0, a random port will be chosen by the host.

If no ports are given, all of the service's ports are forwarded. If native is true, each port maps to the same port on the host. If native is false, each port maps to a random port chosen by the host.

If ports are given and native is true, the ports are additive.
args.name: ports

args.description:
Map each service port to the same port on the host, as if the service were running natively.

Note: enabling may result in port conflicts.
args.name: native

fields.description: Creates a tunnel that forwards traffic from the host to a service.
fields.name: tunnel

args.description: Location of the Unix socket (e.g., "/var/run/docker.sock").
args.name: path

fields.description: Accesses a Unix socket on the host.
fields.name: unixSocket

fields.description:
Retrieves an endpoint that clients can use to reach this container.

If no port is specified, the first exposed port is used. If none exist an error is returned.

If a scheme is specified, a URL is returned. Otherwise, a host:port pair is returned.

Returns a TypeDef of kind Object with the provided name.

Note that an object's fields and functions may be omitted if the intent is only to refer to an object. This is how functions are able to return their own object, or any other circular reference.

types.name: TypeDef

types.description: The `TypeDefID` scalar type represents an identifier for an object of type TypeDef.
types.name: TypeDefID

types.description: Distinguishes the different kinds of TypeDefs.

enumValues.description:
A list of values all having the same type.

Always paired with a ListTypeDef.
enumValues.name: LIST_KIND

enumValues.description:
A named type defined in the GraphQL schema, with fields and functions.

Always paired with an ObjectTypeDef.
enumValues.name: OBJECT_KIND

enumValues.description:
A named type of functions that can be matched+implemented by other objects+interfaces.

Always paired with an InterfaceTypeDef.
enumValues.name: INTERFACE_KIND

enumValues.description: A graphql input type, used only when representing the core API via TypeDefs.
enumValues.name: INPUT_KIND

enumValues.description:
A special kind used to signify that no value is returned.

This is used for functions that have no return value. The outer TypeDef specifying this Kind is always Optional, as the Void is never actually represented.
enumValues.name: VOID_KIND

types.name: TypeDefKind

types.description:
The absence of a value.

A Null Void is used as a placeholder for resolvers that do not return anything.
types.name: Void
